Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 49177-002 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
August 2021 
 
 
 
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Capacity 
Building of Electricidade de Timor-Leste in 
Distribution Network Operation and Maintenance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency of Timor-Leste is the United States dollar. 
     
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  EDTL  –  Electricidade de Timor-Leste  
  TA  –  technical assistance 
       
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Timor-Leste ends on 31 December.  
 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT  1

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Power Distribution Modernization Project will (i) modernize the power distribution 
system  in  rural  and  urban  areas  in  12  municipalities  across  Timor-Leste  and  (ii)  provide 
institutional strengthening and capacity building to Electricidade de Timor-Leste (EDTL).1 The 
project will contribute to the sustainability, resilience, and reliability of the electricity system by            
(i)  installing  electricity  metering  infrastructure,  (ii)  rehabilitating  degraded  sections  of  the 
distribution network, (iii) installing a distribution automation system and a distribution management 
information system, and (iv) building institutional capacity of EDTL. The project is aligned with the 
following impact: access to reliable electricity supply enhanced. The project will have the following 
outcome: power supply reliability and financial performance of EDTL improved. The project 
outputs are (i) service delivery to end users strengthened, (ii) distribution network upgraded and 
regional offices constructed and/or rehabilitated to green standards, and (iii) institutional and 
community capacity for electrical safety and operations strengthened. 
 
2.  The project is estimated to cost $50 million. The government has requested a regular loan 
of $35 million from Asian Development Bank (ADB) ordinary capital resources to help finance the 
project and will provide $15 million of counterpart funds.   
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help EDTL during 2021–2024 implement 
the proposed project; strengthen its corporatization process; and build its capacity for regulation, 
maintenance planning, network operation, safeguards, and financial management to improve 
project sustainability and implementation efficiency. 2 The project will be the first development 
partner loan to the energy sector; better systems, controls, and EDTL staff training will be required.    
 
4.  In 2020, the government subsidized about 70% of EDTL’s cost of supply (more than $100 
million) and has initiated institutional reforms to improve electricity service delivery and sector 
sustainability. To achieve these objectives, the government established EDTL as an autonomous 
public entity on 1 January 2021 dedicated to the power sector. EDTL is establishing new business 
processes as it transitions to becoming a state-owned enterprise, which the TA will support. The 
project will boost EDTL’s procurement, governance framework, financial management, internal 
audit function, and contract management capacity. The support of ADB is consistent with the 
government’s efforts to make state-owned enterprises sustainable, transparent, and accountable.  
 
5.  It is proposed that TA resources, rather than a loan, finance the activities as they focus on 
institutional capacity building and strengthening of the corporatization process. Loan resources 
will directly support the project management unit in implementing the project. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output  1:  Implementation  of  the  Power  Distribution  Modernization  Project 
supported. The TA will provide technical support, including policy advice, sector analysis, and 
project implementation support. The TA will ensure that all necessary due diligence; assessment 
 
1  Timor-Leste has 13 municipalities. The project will cover 12 (Aileu, Ainaro, Baucau, Bobonaro, Covalima, Dili, 
Ermera, Lautem, Liquica, Manatuto, Manufahi, and Viqueque) but not Oecusse. 
2  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Timor-Leste, 2021–2023. Manila.

2 
of technical suitability; and studies of the economic, financial, and social viability of the proposed 
projects are undertaken. The TA will tackle capacity building and institutional issues and identify 
measures to strengthen project implementation. 
 
7.  Output 2: Support to strengthen the corporatization process of EDTL, technical and 
advisory services, capacity development, and implementation provided. The TA will support 
EDTL’s corporatization process by strengthening work plans and road maps and the methodology 
and approach, and prioritizing activities that need to be completed before corporatization. The 
output  includes  regulatory  assessment,  power system  planning,  electrical safety measures, 
electricity tariff analysis, and establishment of technical standards, which will all involve on-the-
job training of EDTL staff. ADB will review all government requests under the output and provide 
support linked to the ongoing corporatization program, while ensuring strong coordination with 
key development partners.  
 
8.  Output 3: Institutional capacity of EDTL strengthened. The TA will provide technical 
experts  in  transmission  and  distribution  grid  enhancement,  system  planning,  procurement, 
financial management, and safeguard implementation and monitoring to build EDTL capacity in 
these areas. The activities include training in (i) power system planning, maintenance, and 
operation (generation, transmission, and distribution) using appropriate planning tools and/or 
software; (ii) economic analysis and financial assessment; (iii) the use of financial management 
software, preparation of financial reports for EDTL management and the Ministry of Finance, 
tracking of expenses per project, and asset management; (iv) preparation of standard bidding 
documents, bid evaluation, and negotiations; and (v) implementation, monitoring, and reporting 
of  project-related  safeguards  on  the  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and indigenous 
peoples. The TA will advise EDTL on adapting advanced or high-level technology in project 
design by adapting such technology to local conditions.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $775,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. The TA scope is expected to be expanded to cover other activities, consistent with 
the TA’s outputs, and the TA will be replenished from time to time as funds are required and 
identified. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of data acquisition, 
counterpart staff, office space and communication facilities, and other in-kind contributions. The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  and  be  responsible  for  the  selection,  supervision,  and 
evaluation of consultants. ADB’s Energy Division, Southeast Asia Department will be responsible 
for TA implementation and work closely with executing and implementing agencies and the project 
implementing unit and in close coordination with the resident mission and other development 
partners. The TA will be implemented from December 2021 to December 2024. The TA will recruit 
a team of individual consultants to help achieve the outputs. Selected core individual consultants 
will be based at EDTL premises or in ADB’s resident mission and work closely with the Energy 
Division staff. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

3

11.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions and Procurement 
Regulations (2017, as amended from time to time).3Survey and other support services will be 
 
provided  by  the consultant following the ADB Procurement  Policy  and  its  associated  staff 
instructions and Procurement Regulations. 
 
12.  A multidisciplinary team of individual consultants will be recruited to carry out activities 
identified under the TA; about 25 person-months of international consultants’ input and 23 person-
months of national consultants’ input will be required. Recruitment will follow ADB's individual 
consultant selection process and will use time-based and/or output-based partial lump-sum 
contracts. Consultants will be deployed based on the requirements of each project component. 
Individual consultant selection rather than firm selection is considered appropriate, because the 
TA involves multiple activities that are not necessarily interdependent and will require a varied 
range of consultants’ expertise and services to support EDTL operations. Since the capacity 
building  of  EDTL  will  have  to  be  undertaken  in  tandem  with  project  implementation,  the 
engagement of individual consultants offers the flexibility necessary to help EDTL implement the 
project.  
 
E.  Governance 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. Thus, the financial management, procurement, and integrity 
risks during implementation are assessed to be low. However, the TA will conduct thorough risk 
assessments of governance subjects for ensuing investment projects.
 
3 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
